section.title: Reading
section.p: Read Sections 1.3 and 1.5 of Applied Discrete Structures.
Response Question: If A is a finite set, why is the number of elements in the power set of A a power of 2?

Also, turn in solutions to these exercises:
Let B=\{0,1\}. List elements of \mathcal{P}(B), B\times B and B\times B\times B.
Calculate \sum_{k=1}^3 (2k-1), \sum_{k=1}^4 (2k-1), and \sum_{k=1}^5 (2k-1). Do you see a pattern?

li.p:
Let X = \{n \in \mathbb{N} \mid 10 \leq n \lt 20\}. Find examples of sets with the properties below and very briefly explain why your examples work.
A set A \subseteq \mathbb{N} with \lvert A \rvert = 10 such that X - A = \{10, 12, 14\}.
A set B \in \mathcal{P}(X) with \lvert B\rvert = 5.
A set C \subseteq \mathcal{P}(X) with \lvert C\rvert = 5.
A set D \subseteq X \times X with \lvert D\rvert = 5.
A set E \subseteq X such that \lvert E\rvert \in E.
(From ) Explain why there is no set A which satisfies A = \{2, \card{A}\}
Are there sets A and B such that |A| = |B|, |A\cup B| = 10, and |A\cap B| = 5? Explain.

Consider the universe of postive integers greater than or equal to 2. Let A_2 be the set of all multiples of 2 except for 2. Let A_3 be the set of all multiples of 3 except for 3. And so on, so that A_n is the set of all multiple of n except for n, for any n \ge 2. Describe (in words) the set \left(A_2 \cup A_3 \cup A_4 \cup \cdots \right)^c.
